<p>This one is a shorty, but that’s what it makes it so nice. Imagine that you<br> have only one dependency in your project, which is some third party library<br> your code builds upon, like jQuery. Instead of having the complete dependency<br> management stack on your shoulders, you just want to use that single file.</p> <p>Usually, you would use a CDN, but you prefer it having it added to your bundle.<br> With a library called <code>request</code>, which allows you to fetch files from a webserver<br> and access the contents in a stream format, you can do the following in Gulp:</p> <pre><code class="language-javascript">var gulp = require('gulp'); var source = require('vinyl-source-stream'); var request = require('request'); var merge = require('merge2'); var concat = require('gulp-concat'); var buffer = require('gulp-buffer'); gulp.task('js', function() { var jquery = request('http://code.jquery.com/jquery-latest.js') /* 1 */ .pipe(source('jquery.js')); /* 2 */ var main = gulp.src('main.js'); /* 3 */ return merge(jquery, main) /* 4 */ .pipe(buffer()) /* 5 */ .pipe(concat('concat.js')) .pipe(gulp.dest('dist')); }) </code></pre> <ol> <li>We request the latest jQuery version from the jQuery CDN. The <code>request</code> package<br> allows for streaming. What we get in return is a readable stream.</li> <li>We create a valid vinyl file object with <code>vinyl-source-stream</code>. This makes it<br> compatible with Gulp</li> <li>Our main file is selected from the file system as usual</li> <li>The <code>merge2</code> package allows us to combine both streams</li> <li>The contents of both streams are converted to text buffers<br> so <code>gulp-concat</code> can handle them.</li> </ol> <p>The use case for this might be limited, but it’s good to know that you can pipe<br> any web resource to your build pipeline. Think of assets that are available online,<br> or any data you want to prepare for your static site generator.</p> <p>The awesome power of streams makes this possible.</p>
